Message.Title: The good old “cash-rich split”
Message.Msg: That Yahoo monetizes its Alibaba and/or Yahoo Japan stakes in a tax-efficient manner. Remember the good old “cash-rich split” idea from a few years ago? Why is no one considering that this could be utilized now? At current prices, Wall Street is pricing in that Yahoo will pay full taxes and fees on any disposal of its Alibaba and Yahoo Japan stakes. If they were able to structure either as a tax-efficient deal, you’re talking about billions of dollars in savings (like an extra $9 billion possibly). There could be some interesting assets coming back to Yahoo as part of such a deal too. At the moment, Steve Ballmer is feeling the pressure from Value Act to further rationalize Microsoft (MSFT). What happens if he decides he wants to throw Bing into a “cash-rich split” transaction between Yahoo! and either Alibaba or Yahoo Japan? Recall that one-third of the value Yahoo! would get back for disposing of their $10 billion Yahoo Japan stake or $20 billion Alibaba stake (at an $80 billion valuation for Alibaba) has to come back to them in the form of “other assets.” What if Bing was a part of that – making Yahoo suddenly a natural search partner for Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft also benefiting from being able to say they’re further focusing?

Nonsense. Your speaking jibberish...get a clue. Alibaba should have IPO 'd when the market was hot. Asia is entering a bear market and Alibaba is going to fetch a lot less now. Markets crashing around the world and if you don't think this is going to cause pain for Alibaba and Yahoo the you got your head in your #$%$.. I hope you all bought your SP index puts earlier this week. I know I do. Bring on the pain!1

Message.Title: Yahoo caught redhanded providing all user information to the NSA
Message.Msg: according to a $20 Billion class action lawsuit. Funny I oould not find this news article on Yahoo "news" but Yahoo homepage had news about some old actresses' diet. Former Justice Department prosecutor Larry Klayman filed a federal class-action lawsuit Wednesday against the nine companies named in a top-secret National Security Agency document published June 6 as partners in the NSA's PRISM Internet surveillance program. The lawsuit seeks $20 billion in damages and attorney fees and an injunction ending the highly controversial program that began in 2007. In addition to the nine companies named in a leaked NSA slideshow as providing government investigators direct, real-time access to their servers – AOL, Apple, Facebook, Google, Microsoft, PalTalk, Skype, Yahoo! and YouTube – the lawsuit targets the CEOs of each company, the telecom companies AT&T and Sprint and their CEOs, President Barack Obama, Attorney General Eric Holder, NSA director Keith Alexander, the Department of Justice and the NSA. Each of the nine companies has denied knowledge of, or participation in, the PRISM program. There are three named plaintiffs in the class-action lawsuit filed Wednesday: Charles Strange, a Pennsylvania father whose son Michael, a Navy SEAL Team VI member, died in Afghanistan in 2011, and California private investigators Michael Ferrari and Matt Garrison. "Defendants' willful acts constitute outrageous conduct insofar as they violated Plaintiffs' and Class members' basic democratic rights, constitutional rights, and exposed them to beyond an 'Orwellian regime of totalitarianism,'" the lawsuit says. "Plaintiffs' and Class members' rights are being surrendered in secret to the demands of unaccountable intelligence and other government agencies, as well as all of the Defendants."

Message.Title: Giant US Government internet spying scandal revealed; Yahoo involved
Message.Msg: The Washington Post and The Guardian have revealed a US government mass Internet surveillance program code-named "PRISM". They report that the NSA and the FBI have been tapping directly into the servers of nine US service providers, including Facebook, Microsoft, Google, Apple, Yahoo, YouTube, AOL and Skype, and began this surveillance program at least seven years ago.

Topic.Title: Yahoo! or Google are the most likely to buy Hulu

Message.Msg: I'm sure Google is bidding.

Topic.Title: Yahoo! or Google are the most likely to buy Hulu

Message.Msg: Yahoo! has made a billion dollar bid for Hulu. The company has plenty of cash to make a billion dollar bid after selling half of its take in Alibaba for around $7 billion. While it has been using that cash to make small acquisitions, it also just inked a billion dollar deal to buy Tumblr. Tumblr, a photo and media focused blog site, is a much better fit than Hulu would be. Not only does Yahoo! already have experience in the photo space, but the service doesn't come with legacy baggage. While new CEO Marissa Mayer has been deftly using acquisitions to further her turnaround effort, Hulu would pull the company off on a tangent. And the content providers who currently own Hulu would likely balk if she tried to turn the service into a more modern product by killing ads, increasing content, or trying to make content more timely. Yahoo! is increasingly looking like it has long-term appeal again, which is why the shares have been heading higher. It's a good option for aggressive investors looking for a turnaround play. That said, the company's top line has yet to turn higher, though it has appeared to stabilize to some degree. Caution is still warranted. The addition of Tumblr, which notably increases the company's ad network, should be a big help. While investors might cheer a Hulu purchase, it has too much baggage for an easy integration.

A complaint is also being prepared for the US DOJ.

Now if I bash gays physically then that is abuse and I should be arrested. But gay bashing behind a computer and specifically anonymous against an unknown person is perfectly legal but not the smartest thing. I myself would never do it but I respect someones right if they do.

Legally there's no basis for a lawsuit. Just as a pervert luring a young kid cannot be arrested until he or she gets caught in the act of physically going to meet the child. Now if these posters went and met their victims face to face and said the same thing they could be in some trouble. But by arresting posters on chat boards would be really frivolous and would not contribute to a better society. A lot of . these so called abusive posts are just stupid kids or adults that are acting tough because they feel anonymous. But I doubt they belong in jail. We have enough frivolous lawsuits as it is putting people in jail. we don't need more big brother infringing on peoples lives. Enough with the big brother attitude.
